docs.lead_paragraph: Sign-up season for President Barack Obama's health care law is off to a stronger start this year. But it's not perfect, and Americans remain skeptical that the government's newest social program is right for the country.

headline.main: Stronger Start for Obama's Health Law This Year
headline.print_headline: Stronger Start for Obama's Health Law This Year

docs.snippet: Sign-up season for President Barack Obama's health care law is off to a stronger start this year. But it's not perfect, and Americans remain skeptical that the government's newest social program is right for the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate late Saturday took care of the most pressing matter before the lame-duck Congress by approving a $1.1 trillion spending bill that funds the government through September 2015.

headline.main: A Few Big Items Are Left for Lame-Duck Congress
headline.print_headline: A Few Big Items Are Left for Lame-Duck Congress

docs.snippet: The Senate late Saturday took care of the most pressing matter before the lame-duck Congress by approving a $1.1 trillion spending bill that funds the government through September 2015.

docs.lead_paragraph: Heather Abbott says One Fund Boston — the charity set up in the aftermath of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings — helped her reclaim a degree of normalcy after losing part of her left leg.

headline.main: Marathon Bombing Survivors Prepare for Charity's Closing
headline.print_headline: Marathon Bombing Survivors Prepare for Charity's Closing

docs.snippet: Heather Abbott says One Fund Boston — the charity set up in the aftermath of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings — helped her reclaim a degree of normalcy after losing part of her left leg.

docs.lead_paragraph: Norman Seabrook’s long reign as president of the correction officers’ union has paid dividends for his members, but has also fed a culture of corruption and violence at the Rikers jail complex.

headline.main: At Rikers Island, Union Chief’s Clout Is a Roadblock to Reform
headline.print_headline: At Rikers, a Roadblock to Reform

docs.abstract: Norman Seabrook, powerful president of Correction Officers' Benevolent Assn union, has exerted enormous control over Correction Dept during his two-decade tenure; investigation by New York Times reveals that Seabrook's influence has fed culture of corruption and violence at Rikers Island jail complex, even as he protected union members, and has stalled attempted reforms.
docs.snippet: Norman Seabrook’s long reign as president of the correction officers’ union has paid dividends for his members, but has also fed a culture of corruption and violence at the Rikers jail complex.

byline.original: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and MICHAEL WINERIP

docs.lead_paragraph: The $1.1 trillion package that cleared the Senate over the weekend was, like many of its predecessors, filled with provisions to satisfy special interests.

headline.main: In Final Spending Bill, Salty Food and Belching Cows Are Winners
headline.print_headline: In Final Spending Bill, Salty Food and Belching Cows are Winners

docs.abstract: Senate clears $1.1 trillion spending package that is once again filled with provisions to satisfy special interests; riders include major victories for companies that provide food for school lunches, cattle farmers, Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Las Vegas casinos and several others; bill is headed to Pres Obama for his signature.
docs.snippet: The $1.1 trillion package that cleared the Senate over the weekend was, like many of its predecessors, filled with provisions to satisfy special interests.

keywords.value: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.

headline.main: In Big Data, Shepherding Comes First
headline.print_headline: In Big Data, Shepherding Comes First

docs.abstract: Big data software companies, which combine copious digital data with industry-specific analysis, are gaining prominence in all business sectors; predictions are that market for big data will hit $41.5 billion by 2018, more than tripling in five years.
docs.snippet: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.
